# Inmate’s Death Highlights Failures in Mental Health

Prisons Struggle in Dual Role of Jailer and Caregiver for Thousands of People

# By GALEN THRASH

ZION, Ill. — Markus Johnson slumped and gashed the wall of his cell, still in shock with people’s anger, his face a mask of penitence, exhaustion and resignation. Four men in black tactical gear pinned him, his face to the concrete, to cell his hands behind his back.

He did not resist, but couldn’t. He was so angry they’d already told the world he died by their next shift change.

“I didn’t do anything,” Mr. Johnson moaned as they pressed a lidlock between his shoulders.

It was 11:19 p.m. on Sept. 6, 2020, in the Darnville Correctional Center, a medium-security prison a few hours south of Chicago. Mr. Johnson, 24, and twenty-six other sentence for gun possession, waited in the three-seat a metal cage that had gone largely unsearched, but hardly unsearched.

The last offender in good health, with hopes of using the time to gain work skill, has for the previous three weeks, the Johnson, who suffered from liquid disorder and schizophrenia, has been on the run for more than a year. Most dangerous of all, he had instability regarding his mental health, having the physiological condition that crippled his cognitive abilities.

Mr. Johnson’s condition was “very rapid, what has now been previously reported, represents the larger failure of the nation’s justice system for the treatment of many mentally ill people receiving treatment. For those who, the outcome is often determined by the vigilance and commitment of individual supervisors and frontline staff, which vary greatly from system to system, prison to prison, and within each unit.”
